Message.Title: Finally, a Yahoo CEO that actually cares about the company
Message.Msg: Say what you want, but I think Yahoo finally has a CEO that cares about the success of the company. You may not agree with all of Mayer's decisions, but it is clear she is doing everything she can to shake things up and turn the company around. Some people may complain about certain strategies, but they are strategies coming from someone who is trying to make a significant impact on the company. Is see a few resistance points in the $20s, then I see a big resistance point at $40.

Message.Title: reporting in at the workplace
Message.Msg: If you feel you aren't as productive at the workplace then you have poor judgement and bad management. I was an IT support person and I got 3xs more done on site than from home. You need to learn how to say no more often and stop the 'hi how are you' 30 minute sessions with friends/coworkers. You are work to work. Make sure if someone asks you for something not work related to go to the appropriate department for that question. I closed 3xs more tickets than remotely. I still used remote software a lot of the time but being on site helped dramatically when I needed my manager or team leader for input. Skype/email/chatting takes too long and is broken communication. I understand if you have a 2 hr commute, but you shouldn't be working when not getting paid unless you are salaried. You have to know that when you sign on the bottom line for that job. I always go hourly no matter what. One virus/major software issue in the corporation and it pays for itself. I have had to sleep on the floor waiting on a vendor. Work is work. Don't like it...work for yourself and become a consultant.

Message.Msg: "It started in China with Alibaba picking their advisors for their IPO" Please provide a link that shows this to be true. From what I have read it was a rumor started by Bloomberg weeks ago that was denied by Alibaba. Alibaba didn't say "no comment" they said nothing had been done. Only the posters on this board have jumped to the conclusion that advisors for the IPO have been picked. Now its this week, last week, some week, any day now...all pure specualtion. So if Alibaba has picked some advisor(s) for the IPO please post a link that shows it. Otherwise so far as we know and as far as Alibaba has told us....nothing has been done.

Message.Title: TALENT RETENTION
Message.Msg: Yeah, so, this is actually a pretty bad sign if you have ever worked in any digital/startup environment. It will cost much more to replace the ones who leave and the ones who still will be 50% less productive. Possibly will seem positive in the short-term bottom line but mid-term this is bad, and long term even worse. Possible good short flip if you are paying attention, but imho this is now an even bigger BIG SHORT. glta

Topic.Title: TALENT RETENTION

Message.Msg: I know a handful of people there and other web shops. Talk to anyone, and you will know that WFH is an important benefit AND STANDARD among internet companies...workers avoid traffic, can perform more and better from further away, and grade A talent can even work in other states. Yahoo will lose these people in favor of clamping down on the workforce for, I don't know, rather stupid antiquated reasons. The weak will stay, the strong will leave...i.e., mgmt simply misses the point: talent goes wherever it wants, and to whatever seems attractive. So ask yourself: If you're senior level and can get the same gig elsewhere, why would you stay at Yahoo which is already the laughingstock of digital? OR, if you are fresh out of college and hold the most coveted skill set in the most competitive markets for talent in the country, do you choose a place like Yahoo or do you go somewhere like Google or a take a chance on a startup that "gets it". It's pretty clear, and obviously Yahoo does not get it. Yahoo thinks it matters if workers have their #$%$ in a deskchair....and ignores that fact that net communication is more important than face-to-face among these TYPES of workers. SO CONSIDER YOURSELF WARNED: If you're a long-term investor, you'd better start looking for way out. If you are an employee shell-shocked by this news, sell your shares and open up a cafe, because life just got stupid. You basically work inside an insurance office, the internet dream is now dead to you....

Topic.Title: TALENT RETENTION

Message.Msg: "Bloomberg reported Alibaba picked Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse as advisors for the upcoming IPO." That was on January 16th...over a month ago...and not only has there nothing more been said but this is what Alibaba said in response to the Bloomberg story... "“We have not hired any banks in connection with any IPOs,” John Spelich, a Hong Kong-based spokesman for Alibaba, said yesterday by telephone"

If Yahoo meets my requirements, I'm yours fulltime.
